@Haiyya_Act @FeminismInIndia #MyGynaecStory The first time I visited a gynaec was with my mom.The gynaec started asking questions about my periods, assuming I wasn't sexually active as I was there with my mom? She didn't even ask her to leave the room & I was just very uncomfortable with the whole situation.
@FeminismInIndia @Haiyya_Act I was told that Tampons and cups were 'for married women' and that I could start using them 'after I got married'
@FeminismInIndia @Haiyya_Act why just unmarried, I am single (divorced) so if I go asking for an IUD or any other thing it is held under a scanner, single moms are supposed to be asexual

@FeminismInIndia @Haiyya_Act Tried to get an IUD. My doctor told me that this could affect pregnancies. Told her I didn't want to produce children. She then said I may want to consult with my husband. Told her I was unmarried. Was told that this was a decision best taken once I was married. #MyGyaecStory

And that's a wrap everybody! Thanks so much for participating in our tweet-chat today. The #MyGynaecStory campaign relies on women voicing their experiences so we can use it to hold service providers accountable, so this was great!
https://t.co/ICanRSjNdn

@japna_p @FeminismInIndia @Haiyya_Act Well in case of something communicable they ask, just guessing :P
Medical service providers are unable to wrap their around the fact that women can choose to not have babies, be unmarried and choose to not marry.  #MGynaecStory https://t.co/8BOh5GuWN1

@SalonieM @Haiyya_Act Apart from the infuriating lack of agency given to you, there are temporary IUDs that you can put in place that can ALSO be removed later, in case you want to have children. It's quite a standard contraceptive procedure. #MyGynaecStory

Very true, moral judgement is placed on single women by medical service providers, whether unmarried or divorced, thus leading to them deprioritizing their sexual health! #MyGynaecStory https://t.co/uTiAbnmNbN
@FeminismInIndia @Haiyya_Act The gynae is likely to take the case seriously in the presence of a male companion.

@FeminismInIndia @Haiyya_Act Sexual or reproductive healthcare services for unmarried women, where they exist, come with conditionality. For instance, unmarried women (and adults) seeking abortion services may be asked to be assisted by their partners/an adult.
@FeminismInIndia @Haiyya_Act I once went to an ENT for my sneezing allergy and I was asked if I'm married. What's the connection, bro? #MyGynaecStory

@SoulVersified @Haiyya_Act Absolutely - female sexuality and desire is so taboo and so unthinkable. If women are not "offering" sex for the pleasure of their husbands, why do they need to have sex at all?
@FeminismInIndia @Haiyya_Act For that matter even widows can and must have a sexual life, and access to sexual health care, do they?

@FeminismInIndia @Haiyya_Act True, so if there isn't a legally accepted relationship which is marriage in an adult woman's life, in India she is supposed to remain celibate. Not have sex, not have reproductive health concerns and the like.

@tinker_toes @Haiyya_Act That sounds awful. The gynaec can definitely insist that your mother leave the room in order to have a private consultation, but unfortunately, unmarried women are perceived as having no agency. Thank you for your sharing your #MyGynaecStory!

Yes! Unmarried women – whether never married or divorced – are put under so much scrutiny for demanding sexual and reproductive healthcare, which they have full rights to do! Well said, @SoulVersified. 

#MyGynaecStory @Haiyya_Act https://t.co/LTD9dwIOhD

@SoulVersified @Haiyya_Act Absolutely – as though women asking for sexual and reproductive healthcare is a right reserved for only for those women who are socially legitimised through marriage! :/ #MyGynaecStory
